text: hey everyone in this video we'll be
covering the different backup and
restore options available with Amazon
Dynamo DV my name is ji and I'm a Dynamo
DV specialist Solutions architect one of
the most common questions I hear from
the customers is what are my backup and
restore options when I use Amazon Dynamo
DV well you have a few and depending on
your requirements you can use different
ones so let's look at these options and
when you can use which the first one is
the on demand backup it basically takes
a full data dump of your table and
you're able to go about it in two ways
the first one is the native Dynamo DB
feature and the second one is using AWS
Backup Service the native Dynamo DB
feature provides you with an instant
backup and you're able to restore it
with or without indexes to the same or a
different region the AWS Backup Service
provides you with more enhanced features
but the backup creation is not
instantaneous basically AWS backup is
service for centralized backup
management across AWS Services it helps
you schedule backups life cycle them to
colder storage tiers for better costs
tag them for cost allocation copy them
across regions and across accounts when
you copy backups across accounts both
these accounts have to be a part of the
same organization also an additional
benefit of using AWS backup is that
additional layer of encryption that you
get which can be different from your
Dynamo DB tables encryption unlike the
native Dynamo DB on demand backup a
backup doesn't let you restore to a
different region you'll first need to
copy the backup to a different region
and then restore it the second type of
backup is point in time recovery once
you enable this on on your table Dynamo
DB maintains uh continous stream of
incremental backups for your table and
the retention period is 35 days so you
can roll back the state of your data
down to any second in those 35 days the
retention period is fixed and much like
the on demand backup the native on
demand backup option you can restore
your table to the same or different
region and with or without indexes Point
time recovery is particularly useful for
production critical workloads where you
want to protect your data from
accidental deletes or accidental
modification another additional
Advantage is if your table with a pit
enabled gets deleted dynb creates a
system backup and keeps it in your
account at no additional cost for 35
days
the options that we talked about so far
are uh not human readable and they do
not provide you with mutable backups in
order to get that you have export to S3
so you can create an export of your data
the full Dynamo DV data at any point in
time which means you need to have point
in time recovery enabled on your table
for this and you are then able to use it
as a part of your data Lake to run
analytical queries or those 10 to 20% of
aggregation queries in S3 uh you can
also transform this data and then get it
imported into uh Dynamo DB or any other
data store of your choice as of now the
supported formats for export are Dynamo
DB Json and Amazon ion a complimentary
uh feature to the exports to S3 is bulk
import from S3 where you can import your
CSV Dynamo DB Json or Amazon ion data
from S3 into Dynamo DV the bulk import
from S3 doesn't consume any wcu or any
right Capac capity units on your table
and uh the S3 buckets in both these
cases the export and the import can be
in the same or different region or in
the same or different
account in a nutshell you have three
different options for backups and two
different options for restores or UT and
none of these options have any effect on
the table's availability or performance
which means you can get these backups
and restores done without hampering your
live transaction traffic
apart from that I think it is important
to note that restores always happen on a
new table even the import from S3
feature is only available on new tables
as of now and the restore times differ
based on the size of the table
underlying partitions and some related
variables but service metrics show that
95% of customer restores complete within
1 hour it is a good practice to
periodically keep uh a track of your
restore times and keep them
documented all right that was it hope
that was useful and thanks for watching
